column1: "statements": "```json\n{\n  \"discussion\": \"Priority of accessibility in city planning for the benefit of all\"
column4: it would benefit everyone if city planning was based around disabled people
column5: seeing as a high tide lifts all boats and everyone is going to lose mobility at some point or another
column7: \n      \"statement\": \"City planning focused on accessibility can improve lives for everyone.\"
column8: \n      \"excerpt\": \"it would benefit everyone if city planning was based around disabled people\"\n    }
column10: \n      \"comment\": \"Yep. More accessible designs are often nicer for able-bodied people as well.\"
column11: \n      \"statement\": \"Accessible designs enhance the experience of all users
column13: \n      \"excerpt\": \"More accessible designs are often nicer for able-bodied people as well.\"\n    }
column15: \n      \"comment\": \"Accessible design makes life easier and safer for everyone but we still avoid it like the plague.\"
column16: \n      \"statement\": \"The neglect of accessible design compromises safety and convenience for everyone.\"

column2: \n      \"comment\": \"I walk around Seattle for a living and it can be really difficult and dangerous for an able-bodied person to get around. I can't imagine the difficulty disabled people have getting around the city. It is so frustrating hearing people not want sidewalks because they dont want to lose parking spots.\"
column7: there\u2019s a strong contingent that use the sidewalk AS their parking spot. No amount of Find-it-fix-it requests seem to change that.\"
column11: \n      \"comment\": \"Place a 'no parking' sticker on the windshield. Search for 'hard to remove parking sticker' on amz.\"
column15: \n      \"comment\": \"Disabled people should have an outsized say in city planning
column16: it makes it so much better\"
column20: \n      \"comment\": \"As a wheelchair user without a power assist navigating Seattle is tough!! The busses are great though so I use them a lot.\"
column24: \n      \"comment\": \"There's one crazy dude who always goes around knocking down every single Lime vehicle he sees. Fucking hate that guy. I always try to move them out of the way if it looks like a wheel chair couldn't get around them easily.\"
column28: \n      \"comment\": \"A list of disabled grievances: 1) The sidewalk in front of your home is your responsibility to clear. Keep it clear edge to edge from ground to 6' high. Cut back or remove from the sidewalk bushes
column36: whatever you're growing on your hell strip
column38: scooters etc. 2) Cars yield to pedestrians
column40: and everyone else. If someone is crossing the street you stop
column41: you don't honk. 3) If you have a temporary disability placard it doesn't mean you should park in disabled stalls. Disabled stalls are for people who need them. If you don't need them
column42: don't use them. If the stall is the wider wheelchair access ramp stall
column43: don't use it unless you or a passenger are in a wheelchair that you have to unload from the vehicle. 4) Leash your dog. Leash it in parks
column47: \n          \"excerpt\": \"The sidewalk in front of your home is your responsibility to clear.\"\n        }
column48: \n        {\n          \"statement\": \"It is vital for cars to yield to pedestrians and wheelchair users to promote safety.\"
column52: \n        {\n          \"statement\": \"Disability placard misuse highlights the urgent need for awareness of limited resources.\"
column53: \n          \"excerpt\": \"If you have a temporary disability placard it doesn't mean you should park in disabled stalls.\"\n        }
column54: \n        {\n          \"statement\": \"Dog owners must act responsibly to keep pathways clear and safe for all pedestrians.\"
column55: \n          \"excerpt\": \"Leash your dog. Leash it in parks
column59: 14 feet above curb and at least one foot back from the edge of the sidewalk https://www.seattle.gov/transportation/projects-and-programs/programs/pedestrian-program/sidewalk-accessibility-guide#homeownermaintainingvegetationandremovingdebris\"

column2: \n      \"comment\": \"Find it and fix it seems to not care about a lot and hyper care about a few issues that Harrell cares about\"
column6: \n      \"comment\": \"I've seen an older woman do the exact same thing
column7: but did not appear 'crazy' in any way. While she's clearly protesting these scooters
column8: she's also making it so they are in the way for every/anyone.\"
column13: \n      \"comment\": \"I pull them out of the sidewalk and toss them on the ground when they are blocking the sidewalk.\"
column17: \n      \"comment\": \"Thanks. So tired of everyone growing their 'native garden' of weeds and woody lavendar over the sidewalk.\"

column2: \n      \"comment\": \"exactly this. its just another prime example of why inclusivity and representation matters. I had this same concern when we were deciding to have kids
column3: too. The number of sidewalks that just disappear and like the article said
column4: curbs cuts are practically non-existent in some areas. Not trying to diminish the article with my own experience of navigating a stroller
column5: just highlighting how ADA accessibility is important and extends beyond the disabled community. It benefits everyone.\"
column10: \n      \"comment\": \"Curb cuts! They are enforced as part of the ADA
column11: but everyone else enjoys the benefits of being able to roll things onto the sidewalk.\"
column15: \n      \"comment\": \"I\u2019ve been walking around my neighborhood with a stroller twice a day for the last month. It gives huge empathy for disabled people now that I\u2019m realized how inaccessible the sidewalks are for wheels
column16: and how at least half of intersections on neighborhood streets don\u2019t have any curb cuts at all.\"
column21: there were many challenges navigating the built environment
column22: especially when it came to sidewalks. The lack of curb cuts was prevalent
column24: the sidewalk was in poor condition.\u201d I didn\u2019t realize how bad the sidewalks are until I had a baby and started pushing a stroller
column25: the city walks are horrible And didn\u2019t the city get sued for like a million for a person that fell walking on the sidewalk? Yet people wonder why I\u2019m upset about Bruce\u2019s $6 million a year \u201ccover up graffiti\u201d spending waste. Literally 0 return on investment
column26: every time the city pants over the graffiti it\u2019s back in like a day.\"
column29: \n        {\n          \"statement\": \"City spending priorities should focus on public safety rather than ineffective graffiti removal.\"

column3: disabled people are constantly harassed for service animals
column4: standing or sitting in the front of the buses (disabled and elderly seating) if they do not look visibly disabled. The slippery slope argument is bullshit
column5: if people constantly have to prove disability (means testing
column7: ensuring they are doing the specific amount of work they are required to do for disability benefit) it seems no different than attacks on other marginalized peoples.\"
column11: \n      \"comment\": \"I\u2019ve had to report bus drivers for refusing to let people with mobility devices onto the bus when all the handicapped seats were empty. I guess they think it\u2019s too much work to deal with? Fucked up.\"
column15: \n      \"comment\": \"Minor nit on #3. If you have a temporary tag
column16: you have a temporary need. This should be no less valid than permanent plates.\"
